author: Lincon Vidal
title: Community-driven content production
description: Producing informational/educational content involves a lot of work, and it's hard to predict what is valuable to the Cardano community

assessments.note:
The main question posed for the "F4: Local Community Centers" is "How can we mobilize the community to solve local problems using Cardano, through a Local Community Center model supported by the CF?"
The proposal that has been put forward does not address the aspect of "Local" in "Local Community Centers" well enough, in my view. The proposed solution "A collab platform for community-driven content production based on content models with built-in token-based governance on content and models" does not define the "Local Community" well enough in my view.
The campaign brief specifies that:
The different LCC categories are: (1) Developers center, (2) DeFi / DAO center and (3) Business center (solving a local problem).
The concept of "community" used by the proposer seems to me to be too vague as I am not sure does the proposer view his/her platform as an LCC and which type exactly? "The goal is to allow the community to participate in the decision making process and content creation."
The proposer does not directly classify his proposal into one of the three, but does specify the following: " To address this problem, we are proposing a collaborative platform to organize community-driven content production".
It leaves me unclear whether by proposing a collaborative platform, this effectively means that none of the three LCC categories has been chosen, or one of them? We are left without a clear answer to what might seem a basic question as it is in the very title of the challenge.

I must commend this proposal for addressing a crucial challenge for the Blockchain network. However, I think you can start by limiting the amount of languages you want the content creators to work on. Why? I believe that this project is going to concentrate on a certain region. I assume south America.

Pick the top spoken languages in Brazil. Keep it small and target your marketing towards those groups.

The proposal appears to answer the challenge quite well in that it will educate others in an interactive manner. This may flow on to ideas being generated that will further enhance Cardano knowledge in the community.

The proposal is very well presented and the sub-structure with Infoblocks is already in place to build upon an existing platform. Education is one of the biggest challenges for this project as the blockchain can mystify individuals that have no way of understanding the technology, the pros/cons and the greatest opportunities that can be unlocked with a little clarity. I like the idea and the solution it presents. Establishing governance is also a very good principle to include and the community has all the tools needed to build on a platform like this. The only thing I would say to the contrary is that an outline for the various stages needed to get there should be good to follow the progress of the project along the way.

The proposal model for content creation is very interesting and has the possibility to be sustainable in the long run. Also, it creates a mechanism through which the equilibrium between content creation and demand will be equilibrated. It seems to be scalable as well, and in the best scenario it could even be used globally and also replicated to other knowledge areas.

Not sure this sits in the right challenge, but it's a good proposal that would help drive Cardano adoption by engaging the existing community at different levels of expertise ( basic users, developers, and technical experts) and would likely bring in new users.

Your proposal does a great job of defining the challenge and explaining your proposed solution to address the challenge. Certain elements of your proposal demonstrate superior due diligence for this assessment area:

--Detailed and clear explanation of the problem you're trying to solve, including references.

--Detailed explanation of the process workflow to produce the desired output, including the roles and responsibilities involved and the steps each contributor needs to complete in the process, unlike other proposals that skip the business processes and jump straight into the technical development details.

According to the relevant experience segment filled in by the proposer: "Our team has been exploring for 6 months the challenging task of educating people about Cardano's technology through the Infoblocks project."
I also visited the link provided by the proposer: https://everyblock.studio/category/infoblocks/
I looked into the "About Us" segment of the website to gauge the relevant experience and was unable to immediately find anything more specific than "We are builders..." "Despite the cutting-edge technology we work with, EveryBlock Studio is primarily a creative space." etc...
The project does propose to engage the services of: a Web Developer, b Blockchain Developer, c. UI/UX designer. D. DevOps. e. IT infrastructure. This means that critical persons would be onboarded.
However, the weakeness may be the proposer's own relevant experience to run a project of this nature as this experience seems to be elusive. In fact, the specified experience "exploring for 6 months the challenging task of educating people " does not seem to be such that "it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully", in my opinion.
Unfortunately, there is no mention of the work experience of the proposers. A little background would help reviewers see who is leading the project.

I do feel that the team is likely to have sufficient knowledge to move the proposal forward however it is unclear where they will be sourcing the team or in fact whether the team already largely exists. Only a minor concern.

Given the extensive proposal brief, set metrics, breakdown on the different departments and the ideas presented with the solutions in principle as well as already existing formats created by the proposer there is confidence that the proposal will be successfully implemented.

The proposer seems to have enough information creation experience, although the proposal will demand more technical knowledge, which will be provided by the team described in the cost structure, which is not already engaged (at least it was not mentioned). The budget is well described as well.

The existing webpage (infoblocks) is built with high standards. The plan to use this as a starting point and to develop the user/community interaction is plausible an well described. The timeline and budget requested are realistic.

One of the main advantages of your proposal is that you already have a working product which you are now planning to "decentralize" and expand it to the community as a platform that can grow. Your Infoblocks website demonstrates that you have the technical ability as well as the right approach to explain complex technical concepts using web pages (e.g., the explanation you provided on how stake pool rewards are calculated). The other elements needed for a high score in this assessment criteria are all there, such as a high level plan and budget, a committed team in place, and demonstrated experience (again, my assessment assumes that you'll use your current Infoblocks website as the foundation for this project).

The project does specify that it " is expected to be developed over 6 months with Brazilian workforce" , but the feasibility of it does not seem to be addressed sufficiently, in my view. It relies on a wide range of diversified contributors contributing to the collaborative platform, however it would be good to have some metrics, some quantitive goals for this period that would allow for the measurement of success or failure. The project specifies that for each content (Infoblock), the team will create an infographic distributed as a static image, a base text detailing the content in more depth, a video with simple graphic animations and narration based on the text. But the proposal does not address how many infoblocks will be produced, how many contributors will be onboarded and other metrics - which makes it difficult to assess feasibility of outcome.

There are steps towards creating a system that works but we need to include storytellers to the mix. Your product needs a story that would stick with those it is trying to reach. Please include marketing in your budget. Sell this project better. It still needs some work.
Well written proposal with good evidence provided and I felt I was able to have a clear understanding of what the proposers are trying to achieve. Budget is reasonable without clarifying all aspects.

There is enough information here to be confident in the proposal and the metrics and work needed to actuate is are well described. The community has the potential to collaboratein the building of the solutions.

Roadmap is somewhat described, although milestones definition would increase the auditability of the proposal, and also the definitions of KPIs. Valuable KPIs in this case would be the platform usage, number of views, content quantity, and others similar.

The risk is that there won't be enough people interested in generation content or enough user interest. An incentive system is described which would work but the proposal didn't didn't success criteria or KPI's

Your project has reasonable feasibility based on the foundation you already built with the everyblock.studio website and the plan you proposed, but you need to describe the anticipated risks and how you plan to mitigate those risks. Also, I think it will be difficult to define measurable metrics to determine the effectiveness of your project: how would you propose to measure how the project is improving education about Cardano? At a minimum you should measure effectiveness by collecting feedback from the users and having a process for evaluating the feedback; for example, having a "Was this article helpful?" link that the user can click on to provide feedback.

solution: A collab platform for community-driven content production based on content models with built-in token-based governance on content and models
experience: Our team has been exploring for 6 months the challenging task of educating people about Cardano's technology through the Infoblocks project.
